properties.Title: Fort Niagara
properties.Explanatory_text: Strategically important British fort, controlling access to the Great Lakes. Site of diplomacy with Great Lakes-based Indigenous nations.

properties.Title: Detroit
properties.Explanatory_text: Strategically important British fort. Site of negotiations between Lieutenant Governor Henry Hamilton, White Eyes, and William Wilson.

properties.Title: Philadelphia
properties.Explanatory_text: Site of the Continental Congress.

properties.Title: Lancaster
properties.Explanatory_text: Yeates' place of residence. This marker shows the location of his home.

properties.Title: Tinian
properties.Explanatory_text: Home of James Burd, Yeates' father-in-law.

properties.Title: Carlisle
properties.Explanatory_text: Yeates stopped here on his way to Pittsburgh. Site of Fort Carlisle.

properties.Title: Fort Pitt
properties.Explanatory_text: Strategically important American fort. Site of trade and diplomacy with Ohio Valley Indigenous nations.

properties.Title: Pluggy's Town
properties.Explanatory_text: Home to a coalition of Mingo, Delaware, Mohawk, Shawnee, and Wyandot people, allied with the British and militantly opposed to settler rule. Named for its leader, Plukkemehnotee or Pluggy.

properties.Title: Tuscarawas
properties.Explanatory_text: A Delaware village notable for its proximity to the Moravian village at TK.

properties.Title: Goschachgunk
properties.Subtitle: Cooshoking, Coshocton
properties.Explanatory_text: "Capital" of the Delaware nation. Yeates' allies frequently sent messages from here.

properties.Title: Fort Randolph
properties.Explanatory_text: American fort meant to defend the western frontier. US-allied Shawnee chief Cornstalk was held hostage and murdered here in 1777.

properties.Title: Sandusky
properties.Subtitle: Sanduske, Sanduske Creek
properties.Explanatory_text: Site of trade between British and Wyandot peoples.

properties.Title: Wheeling
properties.Explanatory_text: American settlement and site of Fort Henry.

properties.Title: Kanawha
properties.Explanatory_text: Approximate site of two American settlements, referred to in the Yeates papers as Big Kanawha and Little Kanawha.

properties.Title: Kittaning
properties.Explanatory_text: Former site of a village of Delaware, Cayuga, Seneca, and Shawnee people. Destroyed by the British during the French and Indian War, and subsequently used as a military camp by the Americans.

properties.Title: Presque Isle
properties.Explanatory_text: A British fort here was destroyed by Seneca, Ottawa, Huron, and Chippewa people during Pontiac's War. Mentioned as a potential site of American military operations.

properties.Title: Le Boeuf
properties.Explanatory_text: A British fort here was destroyed during Pontiac's War. Mentioned as a potential site of American military operations.

properties.Title: Logstown
properties.Explanatory_text: Originally a Shawnee village; later home to Six Nations, Wyandot, Delaware, and other Indigenous peoples, as well as some British and French traders. Destroyed during the French and Indian war.

properties.Title: Shackamaxon
properties.Explanatory_text: Site of the treaty between William Penn and the Delaware signed in 1682.

properties.Title: Gekelemukpechunk
properties.Subtitle: Newcomerstown
properties.Explanatory_text: Delaware "capital" and home of Netawatwes (Newcomer), an important political leader.

properties.Title: Schoenbrunn
properties.Explanatory_text: Moravian mission town with close ties to the local Delaware community. While not mentioned by name, Schoenbrunn was likely one of the "Moravian towns" referenced in the Yeates papers.
